commentBody: This was a fun themeless for me. because the theme went over my head. But I will figure it out ex post facto (since it's too late for ex pre facto).
Pretty good. Got done about 25% faster than my average.
Playdough is actually Playdoh

So the theme is just entries that can be broken up into two unrelated words at each end joined by one of many different words that are synonymous with "join"? 

I think I was expecting some punny revealer or something.  Didn't spark joy for me but hats off to the constructors anyway; better than I could do!
Flew through this one in well under half my usual time. I enjoyed the theme, but thought the clues could be more obscure on a Thursday.

Thanks for the puzzle. ‚Äò‚ÄòTwas fun.

Thank you also for using shading instead of circles.
Thanks. But too easy for a Thursday puzzle.
Great fun. Admittedly easier than usual, but still fun.

First of all, congratulations, Stephan, this is a solid debut and I would expect nothing less given input from Jeff Chen, one of my favorite contributors. The theme was clever, and if I had some disappointment about it, it would be that that the choices for the theme elements seemed a little meh to me. I liked CARBONDATE and TOOKNOTICE; I‚Äôm a little leery of CARAMELDELITES, since that would only be spelled that way for the Girl Scout Cookie, which is a little niche, but given that MELD is a tricky connector I would let that slide; but NINETIESKID seems very green painty (I‚Äôve never heard of that per se‚Äîis it any more special than an EIGHTIESKID or a SEVENTIESKID?) and CREEPINGOUT seems pretty meh. I haven‚Äôt tried too hard to look for better ones but it seems like you could have found better choices for PIN and TIE, and I don‚Äôt like that NINE has the same root as NINETIES. Also for a Thursday I would have liked the ends to be clued more wittily (Auto and Consumed? Also and Frozen Water? That‚Äôs the best you could come up with?)
My favorite parts were actually the NE corner, and then the SW, which had some nice ministacks, some more interesting clueing (I loved the PLAYDOH one) and a misdirect (USSR before CCCP).

I hate to come off too negative because it was a clever idea, probably harder than it looks, and not a bad solve; just felt it had some more unrealized potential. I look forward to more from you soon!
I‚Äôve been finding the Spelling Bee harder than normal the past few days, so balancing that frustration with a few days of fun breezy crosswords has me in better spirits.
SAMOA did not fully fit in the grid. Oh well. CARAMELDELITE it is.

Just wondering‚Äîdo you think red PLAYDOH‚ÄôS REPUBLIC‚Äîan? 
And if so is blue PLAYDOH SO Demo-CRATIC?

(I don‚Äôt mind scooping Mike on this because I know he will come up with something better).
I've liked just about every puzzle I've seen that Jeff Chen had a hand in. But not this snoozefest.
DOH!
This was so good! I figured it out myself without having to use Wordplay. On a Thursday. Yay me! Thanks, Stephan & Jeff. This was just fun. Happy Thursday, y‚Äôall!
This puzzle was not good. It wasn‚Äôt that difficult, just not much fun. And especially disappointing for a Thursday.
I read the column after finishing the crossword, hoping to learn why much of the SW corner is faded out. Any clue?
Very nice Thursday puzzle, bright and fresh! Well done!

I guess some found it easy but I found myself amused and a little slowed down by just how literal some of the answers were. I look at a clue like ‚ÄúOranges, but not apples‚Äù and start assuming it‚Äôs got to be something trickier than CITRUS üòù

And penciled a few wrong before checking crosses. MYBAD/ILOSE, PETCARE/ANIMALS, GEEKS/NERDS.

As Snowball from Animal Farm might have said, Three letters - OPI; five letters - Essie.
Congratulations on your debut, Stephan, and thanks for all your contributions to Crosslandia, Jeff.
(Even though whether this should have run on a Thursday is debatable.)
Fun puzzle - finished well under average but had a good time. Congrats on the first puzzle! I admire Mr Chen for helping so many new people publish their first puzzles.

Seems I must now add ‚Äúnever liked the smell of PLAYDOH‚Äù to the list of ways I felt I did not fit in as a child.

I managed to turn out okay despite this aversion.

GIRLS tripled led me to DOCTOR doubled. As in the Thompson Twins. Not a NINETIES KID, but more of a seventies/eighties kid üòú https://youtu.be/Pf0_Be5PPPU?si=VtlRKQUahr9pKnJN Congratulations on your debut, Stephan. Happy Thursday everyone.
I solved it with a little help but I still don't get it.

Most people found this puzzle easier than average; xwstats.com has this as Easy with the median solve 24% faster than normal.  

But my solve was 58.7% faster than my Thursday average.

Which is good, since I got to it late after an overtime dinner outing.

And so to bed...
One of those times I was in tune with the brains behind the puzzle.the clues were fun.

How many days this week has ‚ÄúELITE‚Äù been an answer? 

Feels more like a Wednesday puzzle

The constructor is from Plymouth Mass.  
why was this puzzle not released for last Thursday?   

I‚Äôm spoiled. Not enough trickery. Or cluing difficulty.  For Thursday. 

But again. This should have been released on Thanksgiving, given constructor‚Äôs location.

If the unclued answers somehow cohered, or related to the two clued halves; if there was some point to having five variations on the word fuse; if the clues sparkled: if there was real cleverness in the overall conception and execution, I would have gladly bowed down to the creators of this puzzle.
Is @deb triggering the Commentariat with PLAYDOUGH or is it a little slip of the keyboard? üòÄ

I spent quite a long time missing that BEaT was actually BEST, which made it GIRLS instead of GIRL A (but I don‚Äôt know a thing about Elvis movies, so it missed me). 

I had fun in this ‚Äúconversation‚Äù :)

Fave entry: NTH for ‚ÄúAdvanced degree?‚Äù

I found the theme underwhelming, especially considering Jeff Chen's involvement. Sets of two straightforwardly clued words joined by terms for joining? Well, ok, but I would expect to encounter an easy gimmick like that on Wednesday rather than today. Most of the clues were also somewhat too direct for this time in the week, IMO.

I only had any issues because of proper names and the like, which is not the sort of challenge I'm looking for. However, I managed without Google. I dredged ELOISE, PLAYDOH and SERTA from deep recesses of my mind (none of those are known here, so I'm only familiar with them because of these puzzles). Of course, I went for USSR before CCCP, but once I realized the cross would be COMES, I was golden.

"The best ones live where craft meets creativity: disciplined enough to satisfy seasoned solvers while also surprising them."
i couldnt have described this puzzle any better.
well done, mr prock.
This was really fun!
A Thursdsy that did not Scam + I as I got the gim and successfully completed it.
Seemed an unusually easy Thursday, even if I didn't get the trick until Deb explained it.

I would question cluing REN as a 'last name' in Return of the Jedi. The character's real name is, of course, Ben Solo, and I at least always thought of Kylo Ren as a sort of nom de guerre or honorific epithet, like Darth Vader or Saddam Hussein. Not a first and last name. But would be curious what others' impression was.

WORDPLAY tells us: "13D. I love clues that trigger our senses. [Toy with a scent trademarked by Hasbro] is PLAYDOUGH, and I immediately recalled that wonderful vanilla-like smell."

but the puzzle tells us: PLAYDOH.

What's a person to do?  We need some BINDing arbitration here.

Regarding 39D, TIL (from Google):

In order to understand Mach speeds, we must first understand the speed of sound. Many people believe the speed of sound is a constant speed, but it actually changes based on several factors. In the air, the speed of sound is most affected by temperature, pressure, and humidity. At freezing (32¬∞ Fahrenheit/0¬∞ Celsius) the speed of sound is about 740 miles per hour. However, at room temperature (68¬∞ Fahrenheit/20¬∞ Celsius) the speed of sound is 767 miles per hour.

Speed-read that, if you can.
Easy for Thursday! More like a Monday.

On the subject of Girl Scout Cookies:

There are two national firms that bake the treats. A troop or a locality decides which bakery‚Äôs snacks to sell. Some similar cookies have two different names, depending on the manufacturer. So the cookies you may know as Caramel deLites, are also known as Samoas. Delicious by any name.

Perhaps this should have been saved for Halloween, as it was more treat than trick. 

And as far as I‚Äôm concerned, Deb can spell the name of stinky toddler paste any randough way she pleases.
That was fun!

Shout-out to [Clutch producer] for HEN. A very fresh and clever clue for a word that has appeared dozens of times. 

And a shout-out to Jeff Chen who, according to Jim Horne of xwordinfo, has hit a significant milestone with this puzzle. It‚Äôs his 117th NYT collaboration, movng him past the previous record holder, Nancy Salomon. 

Congratulations, Jeff and Stephan, on a collaboration that tied everything together very neatly.
Such a fun puzzle! Well done, great first try. Hope to see more‚Äî

Very nice puzzle. It achieves what many others don't these days: a theme that you can actually use during the solve rather than just noticing afterwards. Very satisfying!
Thanks Stephan (great debut) and Jeff!
I liked the idea of this puzzle but I just couldn't crack the grey squares, mostly because they all had either someone's name, brand, or other trivia crossing them

Congratulations to another new crossword setter (using that word in case it's used in a crossword again).

I was a bit bemused by how the theme was set up, and the meaning of the completed phrases, but I'm not good with themes. 

I thought that 'curling' referred to the sport of curling. The sweepers create 'eddies' to influence the stones?
MELON! Sweet. Oldie but goodie. üòÇ
For me the bafflement was the lack of befuddlement, although I was tripped up by the very cleverly clued HEN/INN.  A fine debut nonetheless.  Many thanks.

TIL that ugli is a registered trademark. The fruit is actually a Jamaican tangelo. I wonder if the company that markets this fruit under the ugli name realizes they also hold a monopoly on Jamaican tangelo-related crossword clues‚Ä¶
Hated this one. To avoid more dogpiling from this group, I‚Äôll leave it at that (though, I‚Äôm sure people will still have something to say). Have a great day all!

‚ÄúMission Control? Dis is da rocket. Da launch went okay, what do we do now?‚Äù

‚ÄúARC TILDA ORBIT.‚Äù


( cuz finding another themed was too hard today. fun puzz.)

Wordnerd me loved coming across in-the-language phrases made up of three unrelated words patched together like TOO+KNOT+ICE.

Riddle loving me loved filling in the outer two words (such as TOO and ICE), which were fairly easy to get in this puzzle, then trying to figure out what that middle word is.  

Accomplishment loving me wowed at seeing that the four grayed words were connected.  This could not have been an easy answer set to come by.

Acts-of-kindness loving me beamed at Jeff Chen‚Äôs once again taking an unpublished constructor, and guiding them into a NYT-published puzzle.

Serendipity loving me enjoyed learning CARAMEL DELITE, then being further reminded of cookies when I came across ANIMAL and Hydrox-sounding HYDRA, not to mention getting an extra boost of sweetness with NERDS.

Thus, many lovely pings in the grid today for me, and thank you both.  Congratulations on your debut, Stephan!
Bravo! Wonderful Thursday, lots of fun clues and the gimmick made sense all the way. Two minutes over my average and worth every second.

Didn't have a lot of trouble except for the NE, which was the last to fall. Oddly, my first thought for the letters on Drago's tracksuit was indeed CCCP.  Don't know why, since I never saw any Rocky movie after the first one. But because I solve on paper, I don't fill it in unless I'm sure. When PLAYDOH finally popped into my brain, I could actually still smell it after all these decades.

But the rest of the puzzle was a yawner. Even though I managed to get all four unexciting theme answers, I had no idea what CARAMELDELITE was, other than being annoyed by the spelling. Having now learned they're also Samoas doesn't help much, because I stopped buying Girl Scout Cookies even before my daughter was old enough to join, which she never did. And NINETIESKID???? What's so special about that term that makes it a heavy-hitting Thursday themer? Any different from Eighties Kid? Or Sixties Kid? 

Overall, this ranks with one of my all time least favorite Thursday puzzles, all the more disappointing because I usually associate Jeff Chen's name with positive puzzling.

Here‚Äôs a little nitpick. Americans like to call a beer mug a ‚ÄúStein‚Äù. A Stein is actually a unit of measure, aka the volume of beer, not the vessel. And you would not find a German beer mug (Krug) containing ‚ÄúALE‚Äù, which is an English style of beer. A Krug might have Pils, Weizen, Helles, Bock, or simply Bier, but not Ale.

Nevertheless, Prost to a fun puzzle today. :-)

Loved the puzzle. Fun solve. 
Just a tiny little note to @DebAmlen ... in your commentary, you mention the answer to 13D as "PLAYDOUGH", when, in fact, the real name of it (and the correct answer to the clue) is "PLAYDOH", although in real life there is a hyphen. 
Thanks for all your work. Sorry to be such a pedant, but I kind of had the feeling you might want to know.
Very clever puzzle!

[Andrzej's reaction to a surprise birthday visit to the theatre]









"PLAY? DOH!"

I had to stop and get some popcorn for today's comments.  Deb Amlen, you seem to have far more lovers than haters.  You have gotten me through more than one tough puzzle.  Keep up the good work making the medium sized bucks.

Enjoyable puzzle that should have run earlier in the week. Found the vertical stacks in the NE and SW more interesting than the themers or the theme itself.

Congrats on the debut! Would have been a fine Tuesday puzzle. Guess there's a shortage of Thursday-esque puzzles in the queue again.
Fun puzzle!
Playdoh? Think, Homer. :-o
A bit closer to a Thursday for me since the shading didn't appear when I 3D-printed my stone tablet.

Many have complained about the misspelling of PLAYDOH in the Wordplay column.  Well, I don't care a sou about that.  But Deb's assertion that PLAYDOH has a "wonderful vanilla-like smell"?
Huh???
I almost had to get in my car (in my PJs) and go to my nearest toy store and rip open a can to see if my memory is completely bonkers.
Vanilla?????
PLAYDOH certainly has a distinctive smell, and I, too, love it when a word evokes a forgotten smell,...
But vanilla?????
Have the fine folks at Hasbro added something to the mix in the past dozen years?

I hope someone (with young children, perhaps) will either confirm Deb's assertion...and tell me that I'm loco...or come up with a better way of describing the smell of PLAYDOH.
Either I suddenly got super smart, or‚Ä¶

A short trip in Mr. Peabody's WABAC (wayback) machine to that far away land called the 1980s.

Am I right in recalling that SHEENA Easton, Shiela E., and LISA Lisa were all prot√©g√©s of the singer sometimes called Prince?

No wonder I get them confused.
Too easy for Thursday. Almost 8 minutes faster than my average.

OooohKAY!
This was an interesting way to SPLICE three words together to achieve one two-word phrase, with the added filip that the central word is a "means of connecting."  Wow    The mental gymnastics required to construct this from scratch suggest someone in need of a long, quiet stay in a recuperative setting, methinks.  
And it also meant a lot of short fill that was ...oh, well.  I probably just need another extra-strength tylenol.  That concrete sure was hard!

I was originally thinking what an obscure reference to LUK, the German clutch maker and that nobody but me would get it.
I guess that's what I get for thinking - LOL!

Well, that was different. Tough one for me, but managed to work it all out (from the crosses). Must confess that I remained appropriately puzzled about the theme until after I was done. No big deal. Perhaps appropriate puzzle find today. A Sunday from August 4, 1996 by D. Tuller with the title: "Speesh problem." One theme clue and answer example: Wine connoisseurs at dinner? : SHERRYPICKERS And some other theme answers: BRONXSHEARS SHOOSTHEFAT POLICESHEAF ELECTRICSHARE SHEIKHTOSHEIKH GREGORIANSHANT Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/4/1996&g=3&d=D Finito. ....
What a fun debut! This NINETIES KID loved it, almost as much as I love Captain Planet.
PlayDoh really does smell fantastic. And it tastes good, too. (Yeah, I was THAT kid. Now you know everything.)
Nice puzzle, but I was a bit confused by any lack of reference to the theme in the clues. It only emerged after I completed it.
Completed well before I usually do.Thought it much too easy for a Thursday puzzle. Figured out the twist pretty early. I liked it fine but thought it belonged earlier in the week.

I love that Stephen discovered that crosswords are ‚Äúplayful conversations between constructor and solver‚Äù. Especially when including answers such as Eloise (at the plaza), play doh, Girl Scout cookies, nana, Ronald (McDonald) .. A good reminder to approach a puzzle with a dose of whimsy. 

Bravo to the debut!

I laughed when I saw PLAY-DOH as the answer to 13 D (Toy with a scent trademarked by Hasbro). Ages ago, I taught an introductory professional writing class that included advertising and one year brought in mini containers of the product and gave it out to my students so they could consider its features/benefits. One student commented on the scent and I realized they were right‚Ä¶the scent was a product benefit. Who can sniff it and not feel comforted? From then on (don‚Äôt judge me, if you haven‚Äôt already), I kept a container on my desk and took a whiff from time to time on a stressful day. Honestly, I can‚Äôt recall a time it didn‚Äôt bring me comfort.

NAURU was an answer on Jeopardy last night, with an almost identical clue to the one we had the other day. Now I'm not a conspiracy theory guy, but that's a mighty big coincidence. None of the contestants knew the answer, by the way.

Yes, I know they're called answers and questions, but this is a crosswords forum.

I find it irksome that some folks found this too easy.  There are all levels of people doing the puzzles, beginners, etc., so how can a puzzle suit everyone?  It‚Äôs like trying to describe a smell.  (See what I did there?)  The crossword is not an Olympic sport.  Would you say, ‚ÄúThis long jump was too hard‚Äù or ‚Äúthis marathon was a piece of cake?‚Äù  It‚Äôs all a matter of degree.  No one is forcing you to do the crossword, so why complain?  Some are easy, some are hard.  I guess I need to stop reading the comments.    you kids need to get off my lawn.
Great puzzle.  It didn't harsh my melon too much for a Thursday.

Tough for a Mon-Wed and occasionally Sunday doer! But I kept at it! I don‚Äôt love when the answers are particularly crossword-y do you know what I mean? I‚Äôm the same when I play trivia. Nature of it though. Commenting because I saw the games team on Instagram. Someone said that you guys really do read the comments and the feedback!! A wholesome group of people. Thanks for all you do!

An unusual Thursday for me, in that I solved it before reading the column. Grateful for the lack of rebus, although I was on the lookout for it. But the fun theme gave me the impetus to dive in more eagerly than I usually do for a Thursday (while my darling husband did the laundry!). 

I was surprised when I finished it, way under my usual Thursday time, which is not saying much, so don't feel bad if it took you longer than usual. My usual is nothing to brag about!

Nothing much planned for today, so I'm glad this is done and I can now put away laundry, and then call on a neighbor who hasn't been well. Maybe we'll bring them lunch today. 

Have a fun Thursday!
Well today I learned there‚Äôs two meanings of secrete.

Congratulations on a fine debut, Stephan -- I hope we see more of you! I also enjoyed your insightful and reflective constructor notes! 

A humbling experience regarding PLAY-DOH: While attending graduate school some years ago, I had an in-demand (and, fittingly, demanding) professor whose words always had us at the edge of our seats. During my first class with him, I could not make heads nor tails of what he was talking about until he said what I THOUGHT was, "Take PLAY-DOH for instance ..." I thought, "Well, finally, some kind of connection to my (un-evolved) brain" and added it to my notes. He spoke more at length and then said, "On the other hand, Aristotle ..." I quickly put my hand over my notes and quickly got caught up on my philosophers!üôÑ

Happy Thursday, everyone!

Further to Tom Stoppard's recent death, there is an excellent appraisal of his love and use of words here: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/11/29/theater/tom-stoppard-arcadia-travesties.html Reading it reminded me of why some of us keep choosing to be puzzled in this peculiar wordy way. I have loved Stoppard since Rosencrantz, etc. and my world feels a little emptier today.
I wanted ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll find a way‚Äù to be LIFE, per Jeff Goldblum.
Fun puzzle; thank you!

No complaints - this was middle-of-the-road for me. Decent time. (Slate before CEDAR, CRANKSup before IT) Respected the construction. 
Just didn't send up roman candles.
A rather mild Thursday puzzle but fun nonetheless.

Wow, a rebus free Thursday. While I‚Äôve grown to admire, if not love, a rebus I appreciate the work that generally goes into constructing them. That said, a relatively easy rebus free Thursday is just what the doctor ordered in my currently chaotic life. Not that you can get a doctor in the mess that is our National Health Service, but that‚Äôs a tale for another day.

As a relatively newbie I was surprised that I found a Thursday puzzle to be fairly easy. That‚Äôs not a complaint! I enjoyed not being frustrated beyond belief. I was very surprised that I figured out the ‚Äúconnection‚Äù between the shaded squares before finishing all of them. It helped me solve the puzzle. 

My last square was a guess, the G for geo/GPS, it was a Doh! moment for sure.

I thought today's puzzle was a bit middling.  Puzzles are best when you get the 'Lightbulb moments' where you puzzle over an indirect clue for a while and when you finally figure out you think "Ha, thats clever".  All the indirect clues in this puzzle when you figured them out were more "Oh, ok.  I guess that makes sense."

Is there somewhere you can find a list of 3-5 letter beauty products?  I need to go there and memorize it for future crosswords.  Feels like they're the last squares I fill in every puzzle.

Whew! One more puzzle find. This one quite amazing, with 11 theme answers that never appeared in another puzzle. This one was all in the clues. Anyway - a Sunday from December 11, 1988 by Mel Taub with the title: "Tom Swifties Redivivus" Some theme clues and answers: "___?" asked Tom abstractly : BUTISITART "___," said Tom initially : IOWNANRCA "___," said Tom haltingly : ICANTGOON "___," said Tom flatly : FINDANAPARTMENT "___," said Tom automatically : IPULLEDAGUN "___," said Tom grandly : NICEPIANO "___," said Tom privately : YESSERGEANT And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/11/1988&g=110&d=A ....
Honestly, it seemed awfully easy for a Thursday, and the payoff for getting the theme, (though not much of a theme) just wasn‚Äôt very interesting..
This was a perfectly acceptable puzzle. I still miss tricky Thursdays.
Excellent puzzle Stephan and Jeff! A lot of fun. And Stephan, please do a pun-filled puzzle, the wilder the better. Some of us really like the highest form of humor.

But... Why? The 'theme' entries in 'fusing' the clues together weren't overly hard to solve (mere seconds off my p.b.), but without a revealer or a puzzle title or anything they just felt....  out of place? No mention of them elsewhere in the list of clues, the phrases had no real connection to the answers or clues they stuck between.    

Sure, we can stick a word between two other words and it makes a third phrase, but to what end?
Well, I learned something today. Never knew Samoas had another name!

Way too easy for a Thursday. I guess sometimes they‚Äôre stuck with taking whatever they can find because there‚Äôs nothing else to put for a Thursday‚Äôs tricky puzzle.

There was no trick to it because you could use all the intersecting words to figure everything out.
The column says 13D is spelled PLAYDOUGH, but it's actually PLAYDOH in the crossword puzzle, which is correct since that's how the brand name spells it. This warrants a correction.

One more late puzzle find. This one somewhat similar to today's puzzle. A Sunday from July 8, 2018 by Bruce Haight with the title: "Person/place/thing." Some sample theme clues and answers: "Singer / City / Home feature" ALGREENBAYWINDOW "Socialite / Resort / Store" PARISHILTONHEADSHOP "Political commentator / Geographical area / Fitness routine" OLIVERNORTHPOLEDANCE "Actor / Transportation hub / Part of a broadcast" SEANPENNSTATIONBREAK "Comedian / State capital / Record store section" RICHLITTLEROCKMUSIC "Actress / Mideast area / Crime" MAEWESTBANKHEIST Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/8/2018&g=52&d=A ....

My, my, my. Most everyone seems cranky and not too nice today! 

Stephen, believe it or not, some of us enjoyed your puzzle! It was a great debut! I hope to see more from you.
Kind of limp. I'll add my name to the list of those who found the whole theme unsatisfying. Finished and left feeling like, "what was the point?"

This was a lot of fun. Was a little worried because I started off with nothing in the NW, and in fact that is the corner where I finished as well.

I can't imagine the kind of mind that could come up with five fun phrases, each that begin and end with perfectly cromulent words and have a center that is a synonym for "join."

The fact that the first and last words appeared to have nothing that "united" them and the five theme phrases did not appear related made the theme slightly slower to appear. Which added some needed crunch, as far as I was concerned. In the end, it was their pattern, their rhythm, that united them into a satisfying whole.
What a terrific debut! I loved it. Hope to see more from you, Stephen Prock, on your own or with a great coauthor like Jeff.

Other than starting with "shake" for 1A, it went very quickly. 

I wonder if calling CEDAR shingles "shakes" is a New England thing. It's almost the very last definition on M-W for the word "shake" as a noun. 

Are they called "shakes" elsewhere? I don't recall ever seeing them when I lived elsewhere, so I have no personal experience that provides an answer, despite living all over this country in my younger years.

Deb, thank you once again.  I had figured out the "fuse" theme, but was stuck on the Ivan Drago clue and on the top right section.  After you graciously provided the Ivan Drago clue, the rest fell into place.

I did have a couple of lookups; I try to look things up indirectly so I can learn about them rather than typing the NYT clue into Google.

Fun, though I wish the resulting theme phrases had some commonality other than their construction.

Also that Dallas one center trivia is niche and in a killer spot, nearly forces a lookup given the obscurity if the cross and the fact that it's a non guessable name even with one letter remaining.

As almost always, niche trivia makes great puzzles require lookups.

That's such a waste.

Nice debut, with some clever clues. It took me a little bit to catch on to the theme because I couldn't remember the actress's name. Helga? Tessa? Hilda? Mulva? Finally, NINETIES KIDS became apparent to me, and all was well. Thanks for the fun!
Cruised right along till the NE corner. Thanks for nothing, MARA and TILDA!
Fun puzzle, but Stop right there! with INN is weak.
I enjoyed this puzzle very much
Great puzzle. I do want to argue about that green shade being considered "deep" but I supposed I have other hills to die on today.

A clever meta puzzle but again with the theme of ‚Äúsuck it up buttercup‚Äù and turn on your ESP cap bc no revealer clue given and I don‚Äôt want to read spoilers (as much as I do enjoy the commentary afterwards) before I do the puzzle. Also grateful for the archives and other puzzle sources that give me an actual crossword puzzle. So missing the bygone days of Eugene T. Maleska‚Ä¶he earned his wings and halo!
Anyone else feel a bit naughty after filling out the NE corner? Maybe it's just me (my mind hasn't left the gutter since adolescence)

Occasionally I'll try to come up with another entry of my own for the puzzle. The best I could do for this one was 

Prohibit + Ditty

BANJOINTUNE

I guess I'll stick to solving puzzles not making them. üôÇ

p.s. Nice one, Stephan and Jeff

SERTA/TARS and INN/HEN tripped me up. Never heard of HORA before, always fun to learn something new.

Thanks for a fun puzzle!

Another late puzzle find. I'm from the Upper Peninsula of Michigan and... for no discernible I happened to think about one city with an unusual spelling (and pronunciation) - Sault Ste. Marie. And.. it was an answer in two puzzles. One of those from 1952, but the other one a Thursday from May 9, 1996 by Cathy Millhauser. The four theme answers in that one: SIOUXCITYIOWA ABOYNAMEDSUE NOTWORTHASOU SAULTSTEMARIE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/9/1996&g=53&d=A And... was a bit surprised that the only one of those other answers that ever appeared in another puzzle was NOTWORTHASOU. ...
Two days in a row with delightful solves. Just enough to keep you on your toes today.

@MikeW The way I see it, the clues of the form [A + B] have three parts: a word defined by [A], a word defined by [+] (i.e. a synonym of [join] or [add to]), and finally a word defined by [B]. When the parts are "joined", the result forms a meaningful entry (which is not defined separately; that would probably have made it much too easy for a Thursday).

As a bonus, the use of shaded boxes instead of circles makes the joining word a little like a hyphen (if you look at it the right way).

@R. Finn I agree with people that this puzzle seemed like a Wednesday or Tuesday level gimmick. But I like your hyphen idea. If the constructors had figured out a visual way of representing the hyphen as a rebus square and then clued them down as the whole word (ie "insured" =bond-E-D or "have a wild night" =tie-O-N-E-O-N) then it might have had that fuller Thursday feeling of depth and cohesion.

For most of that time I did SB on my own, only consulting with my wife occasionally. I usually got to Amazing that way, and to genius only once or twice a week. However, for a month or two now my wife has been doing NYT games herself, and for some reason that has improved my performance, too, even if we don't consult on a puzzle. I haven't missed Genius in weeks now. I've always thought everything my wife touches becomes better, and this is more proof üòÉ

Gout is the thing fat nobles used to get on their toes back in the early modern era - alcohol, fat, sedentiary lifestyle contributed.

@Andrzej

After the CLOTBUR fiasco back when SB was new, it seemed that the pangrams were usually selected to be words that people recognized.  Sometimes, when there were multiple pangrams, one of them could be a little iffy.  But if I found a pangram that seemed iffy to me, I'd look for another; I figured there had to be more.  And generally, there was.

The other day, the satellite communications word raised my eyebrow.  I thought that was a rather technical term to hang a puzzle on.

I go through spurts when I get QB three times in a week or five in two weeks, and I think, maybe I'm getting better at this.  But then I get a stretch of a month when I don't get it at all.

Some of it, I think, is the selection of acceptable words, but some of it is that I have busier and less busy times.  And to get QB, I definitely have to be able to go back to it multiple times.

If it's a day when going back to the puzzle doesn't yield any new words for five minutes or so, and I've gotten to Genius, I just let it go.

I'm glad to be a Genius.  Now, despite the fact that I'm the only one of us who does SB, there are always two Geniuses in our house.

It seems to me that SB is a game in which the learning curve stops after a certain point.  I think I've hit that point.

commentBody:

I don't mind seeing negative comments about a puzzle, but I think that, if it's worth your time to come here and post it, you owe us an explanation of *why* you didn't like it.
@The X-Phile See? Someone always has something to say here. üòÇ

@The X-Phile

I think in fairness to D, they have been bashed more than once for negative comments even when they have gone into more detail (sometimes sarcastically so when it wasn‚Äôt entirely warranted) so they may be a little shell shocked and don‚Äôt want to put in the effort. I have a personal sense of when someone‚Äôs really mean spirited in this forum and when they are just vocal and have less of a filter, and I put D more into the latter category and has gotten a bad rep.

@SP

Maybe people are just envious of the big D.
@SP, I appreciate you! People can post three word ‚ÄúI loved it‚Äù posts and nobody bats an eye but when I say I didn‚Äôt like it, it turns into a full on interrogation.

@D

Because "I loved it" doesn't imply the need for improvement.

"I hated it" isn't particularly useful to anyone.

If anyone criticized your dislikes, it could have been that what you said didn't make sense to the trained eye (possibly because you overlooked or misunderstood something).

Did you call a constructor "lazy" or used the phrase "too clever by half"?
@D It's helpful to constructors (especially us unpublished ones) to add a comment or two on what you didn't like. I for one can use all the negative advice I can get.

@Steve L

Well, to be honest, ‚ÄúI loved it‚Äù isn‚Äôt very useful for anyone either except the constructor‚Äôs ego; as both a constructor or a contributor to this forum I like to hear why so I can learn. I especially cringe when I see ‚Äúthis was the best puzzle ever!‚Äù and nothing else; I don‚Äôt dismiss the poster‚Äôs right to an opinion but I‚Äôd sure love to know what they saw in it and what experience they have to satisfy my own curiosity.
I‚Äôve also seen people respond to D in a surprisingly condescending way when it‚Äôs obvious they are a smart  person and it‚Äôs not a question of misunderstanding. We saw this yesterday; I didn‚Äôt care for the tone of their comment either, but the response of basically ‚Äúwhat, was it too hard for you‚Äù was uncalled for and not D‚Äôs point.
I agree ‚Äúlazy‚Äù is always triggering for me; I don‚Äôt mind ‚Äútoo clever by half‚Äù, though, because that just means the constructor sacrificed a good solving experience for a clever theme; I usually still appreciate those puzzles but certainly respect those who don‚Äôt.
Basically my overall point is many of us are very quick to dismiss the negative posters when they often have legitimate points to make and we can learn from them. I will happily raise my hand and say I think Andrzej and D have made me a better constructor and I think about what their criticisms may be when I am creating a puzzle. I may ultimately dismiss them‚Äîwe are different, after all‚Äîbut I take them into consideration when I may not have otherwise.

@Nik

In a Kneipe or Biergarten, you would get your Bier in a Krug, but aren't those (hideous?) ceramic or pewter mugs called Steine?

Of course, it doesn't matter for the puzzle. The clue doesn't mention Germany at all.

And, in case you want to improve your colloquial English, one should say "Here's a little nit I'd like to pick."  The problem is the "nit", the activity of dealing with it is the "nitpicking".

(Enough pedantry, indeed!)

@Reader

A pedantry pile-on!  I love it!

@Nik It doesn't really matter how STEIN is used in Germany, or in German. In English, a STEIN is an ornate mug, often with a hinged lid. https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stein Any kind of beer or ALE could be served in it. Even Diet Pepsi, although that would seem a little odd. But it wouldn't make is less of a stein. (BTW, the English translation, stone, is also a measurement in the UK, but one of weight, equal to 14 pounds.)

Folks are right, it doesn‚Äôt matter how it‚Äôs used in German. Let‚Äôs stick with English. In English, ‚ÄúStein‚Äù refers to these things: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beer_stein. We can assume the puzzle makers meant these. The use of STEIN‚ÄôS CONTENTS to elicit the answer ALE would then suggest a special association between hinge-lidded, Germany-themed souvenir mugs and a specific English beer. Where‚Äôs that coming from? It‚Äôs like the clue referring to a ‚Äúswoosh‚Äù and the answer is ‚ÄúAdidas.‚Äù (Unless we‚Äôre just imagining an Errol Flynn-style fantasy setting with Friar Tuck enjoying his foamy pint out of a decorative tankard, in which case, bottoms up!)

@Mimi

Just a small respectful suggestion‚Äîwhen you are commenting on an error or typo in the article, especially later in the day, please check earlier comments to see if it has been brought up already. This one has, ad nauseum.
@Mimi. IMO, no one should feel obligated to read all the comments before posting their own.  It‚Äôs perfectly fine if certain points are repeated.

@Tom

I specifically restrict that suggestion to comments related to typos or factual errors in the column. They are usually pointed out quickly and frequently and it doesn‚Äôt take much effort to see that. I just think it‚Äôs a polite thing to do both for other folks who like to scroll through the comments and so you are not piling on to the columnist who may already be embarrassed. I personally would be grateful if someone pointed that out to me nicely; but by all means if it‚Äôs too much of a bother, and you don‚Äôt care whether you are the 50th person to mention it, have at it!

My last published puzzle was a double rebus and at that time they admitted they were trying to tone down on those as well unless they were particularly apt‚Äîthey took it anyway and I‚Äôve certainly seen a bunch more since then. I do like to call out people if they are elitist about it and seem to put down people who find it too difficult; but that‚Äôs rare in my experience. I also get annoyed by people who call a puzzle ‚Äúbad‚Äù because it‚Äôs  too easy or seem to be way off base about their expectations; but even then they have a right to their opinions and to post here, and I just respond with my own opinion. Although I didn‚Äôt know he was the architect for that specific building, he was so famous, and so frequently featured in the crosswords, that it was a gimme for me. Five-letter architect (no matter how it‚Äôs clued)? I.M. Pei. Three-letter singer? Ora or Ono. Four-letter place in India? Agra. Four-letter Native American tribe? Otoe or Cree. A lot of the skill in doing these puzzles (and the part that becomes easier the more you do them) comes from remembering these frequent flyers.

I got it pretty quickly, got TOOKNOTICE on crosses, then saw KNOT in the middle and it was obvious that there would be a connecting term connecting the two words. It‚Äôs not ESP and it‚Äôs not suck it up, I would certainly prefer an extra theme entry rather than a revealer which didn‚Äôt need to be there. I personally would have preferred no shading which would have made it more fun for me, as well as more cryptically clued words on the ends, but I think those days of more challenging Thursdays may be gone with the wind, and would certainly have engendered even more complaints on this forum (‚Äúhow can anyone have solved this thing‚Äù), and even if the constructors had planned it that way or preferred it would probably have been nixed by the editors who I really do think are trying to make crosswords more accessible, for better or for worse.
